author: RUSSELL. BERTRAND.
title: HISTORY OF WESTERN PHILOSOPHY. And its connection with political and social circumstances from the earliest times to the present day.
publisher: George Allen and Unwin Ltd. London. 1946
description: FIRST U.K  EDITION. 1st impression. 8vo.(8.8 x 6 inches). 916pp. A fine and bright copy bound in recent full brown morocco. Spine with raised bands, the compartments ruled, lettered and decorated in gilt. Red title label, gilt. Single gilt ruled border on boards. Top edge gilt. ------- A finely bound copy of Russell's hugely popular history, broadly covering covering philosophers and philosophical thought from the Pre-Socratics up to John Dewey and William James, and finishing with Logical Analysis. Russell won the Nobel prize for Literature in 1950, with the Nobel committee listing this title among the works that influenced their decision. While criticised by some as being too general, many found the book an accessible and easily readable introduction to Philosophy and it became a best seller which has not been out of print since.

description: FIRST EDITION. 4to. This volume reproduces the original pages with their typed text and hand written titles, plus photographs placed in and around the articles. Colour printed stiff card covers. Some minor rubbing to the extremities but overall a very good copy of this interesting book. A great insight into the emerging Punk scene, probably the most exciting thing to happen to music since Elvis first curled his lip and wiggled his leg.

author: BAYNES. PAULINE. ( GRIMM. BROTHERS ).
title: WATER COLOUR PAINTING OF HANSEL AND GRETEL. Illustration for Grimm's Fairy Tales.
description: ORIGINAL FULL COLOUR ARTWORK. The image shows Hansel and Gretel stood in front of the Witch, who is holding her broomstick and has her black cat on her shoulder. In the background is the beautiful house covered in biscuits, cakes, sweets & icing. The painting is signed by Baynes in the bottom left corner. Image size is 9.2 x 7 inches. Mounted to give a total size of 16.1 x 13.5 inches. The reverse of the painting has Baynes' agents stamp in black ink. Framed and glazed in attractive maple frame. --- A beautiful painting by one of the great twentieth century book illustrators, best known for her work on C. S. Lewis' Narnia series and J. R. R Tolkien's Tom Bombadil, Farmer Giles of Ham and Smith of Wooton Major. --- Through a contact I had who knew Pauline Baynes I sent a copy of this painting to her shortly before she died to see if she could supply any more information. All she could remember was that she had painted it for the publishers Blackie in about 1949 or 1950 as part of a series of watercolours they commissioned for an edition of Grimm's fairy tales that was intended to be issued in the early 1950's. Despite intensive searches for some years I have not been able to find a copy of that 1950's edition either for sale or listed in a library and think it may never have been published in its fully illustrated form. I have seen a copy of a 1960's edition with only one full colour plate, Snow White, as the frontispiece. Other scenes painted by Baynes from Grimm stories illustrate the dustwrapper but not this image and Baynes is not credited as illustrator in the book or dustwrapper. A copy of this book with the colour illustrated dustwrapper is included with the painting.

author: CHURCHILL. WINSTON SPENCER.
title: MAN OVERBOARD. An episode of the Red Sea. --- In The Harmsworth Magazine.
description: FIRST EDITION. Disbound - two pages (pp661 - 664), printed both sides. (9.3 x 6.2 inches). Three mono illustrations by Henry Austin. Very good clean pages housed in a fold over protective paper within hard bound navy blue cloth covers with gilt lettering to the front board. ------- The only short story by Winston Churchill to be published, which featured in the 1899 Harmsworth Magazine. Assumed to have been written in March 1898 since Churchill sent it to General Ian Hamilton in late March or early April of that year with the following note "The story I send you as it may amuse you for an hour on the voyage". The story and illustrations cover thre of the sides with a full page illustration by Charles Robinson, around a verse titled "In praise of Baby" on the other.  --- Cohen. Bibliography of Winston Churchill ; C72a.

Patterned grey and white endpapers with rampant lion and Churchill's initials, designed by Lynton Lamb. In the publishers original dustwrappers with the same design background. Some toning to the spines, a small patch rubbed off on volume four, and also a few tiny chips and creases to the edges but generally very good wrappers with the spine lettering, including the red volume numbers and titles, faded but still readable on all six volumes. The red ink used for the volume numbers and sub titles is particularly prone to fading and copies without total fading of the red, like this one, are hard to find with it faded to being unreadable on many sets. A nice set of first editions of Churchill's monumental history of World War Two.

author: GRAVES. ROBERT.
title: I, CLAUDIUS. --- &  CLAUDIUS THE GOD. From the autobiography of Tiberius Claudius. And his wife Messalina.
description: FIRST EDITIONS. 1st printings. Two volumes. 8vo. (8.6 x 5.8 inches). Each volume with a folding family tree at the end of the text. Overall a very good bright set. Finely bound in recent full black morocco. Spines with five raised bands, the compartments ruled, decorated and lettered in gilt. Single gilt ruled borders on boards. Top edges gilt. A fine pair.  ----- Largely works of fiction they are written in the form of an autobiography of the Roman Emperor Claudius, and tell the history of the Julio-Claudian dynasty and the early years of the Roman Empire, from Julius Caesar's assassination in 44 BC, Caligula's assassination in AD 41 and through to Claudius' accession, and ultimately to his death in AD 54. Though the narrative is largely fictionalised, most of the events depicted are drawn from historical accounts of the same time period by the Roman historians Suetonius and Tacitus.  Both books were adapted by the BBC into the award-winning television serial I, Claudius in 1976.

author: CHURCHILL. WINSTON. S.
title: A SPEECH BY THE PRIME MINISTER... IN THE HOUSE OF COMMONS, AUGUST 20th 1940.
description: FIRST EDITION. Printed stapled wraps. 16pp. (9.5 x 6 inches). Some minor creasing and a few light marks to the covers. Staples a bit rusted but still firm. A bright, clean copy throughout. Overall a better than very good copy of this fragile pamphlet. Housed in a felt lined clamshell box with black morocco spine, raised bands, decorated with Rampant Lion device in compartments, ruled and lettered in gilt. Black cloth on boards.  Printing and the mind of man. No.424 -----The Lion`s Voice. "If the Gettysburg Address is one of the most moving statements of democracy confronted by tragedy, Churchill`s historic exhortations are its equal in their ringing assertion of democracy confronting the seemingly irresistible forces of tyranny".  First edition of Churchill`s famous rousing speech, commenting on the first months of the war and giving thanks to British Airmen. "Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few".

author: KIPLING. RUDYARD.
title: IF.
publisher: Doubleday, Page and Company. New York. 1910
description: FIRST SEPARATE EDITION (U. S). Precedes the first U.K separate edition by 4 years. Oblong 8vo. (4.4 x 6.4 inches). 8 double leaves, uncut at the top and tid with yellow braided cord. Each double leaf has a dark green rule and dot border, the text printed in black with green initial letters. Half title has "IF" printed in green within an ornamental black panel, the same printed onto the front board, but in red, with the addition of the author's name. This version with the green colour printing is Richards' variant a. The text pages are a bit loose in the binding, but still attached, otherwise a very good copy in the publishers original light brown paper covered boards; - Richards' binding variant iii (a)- , with a couple of small chips and some rubbing and bumping to the spine, and a little minor marking to the rear board but overall is a very good example.  The Publishers note on page 5 appears in four different variants, with priority unknown, and this copy has variant iii.   An attractive copy of this uncommon little book. Published (probably November 1910) very shortly after the Poem first appeared in the book Rewards and Fairies (October 1910), this separate publication was issued to capitalise on the huge, and instant, popularity of what has become Kipling's most enduring work of verse. A poll taken by the BBC in the UK in 2005 voted it as Britain's favourite Poem, poling twice as many votes as the number 2 choice, Lord Tennyson's The Lady of Shallot. Originally written in 1895, IF was inspired by the actions of Dr. Leander Starr Jameson, a British Officer whose forces were defeated by the Boers in 1895, but who was portrayed as a victorious hero by the British press, the poem is a powerful masterclass in maintaining the British stiff upper lip.   --- David Alan Richards; Rudyard Kipling. A Bibliography, A244.

author: WILLIAMSON. HENRY.
title: SALAR THE SALMON.
description: FIRST EDITION, 1st impression. 8vo. (7.4 x 5.1 inches). Illustrated title page decoration and a small vignette on the last page engraved by C. F. Tunnicliffe. A fine copy, finely bound, for Asprey of London, in full dark blue morocco leather. Spine with five raised bands, each decorated with a gilt dotted line. Compartments ruled, decorated with Salmon motifs and lettered in gilt. Boards with gilt ruled line borders. Board edges decorated with large and small dots in gilt. Marbled endpapers. Turn-ins ruled and decorated in gilt. All edges gilt. A fine and attractive copy. The binding is signed by Asprey but the Binder name on the inner front board has been blocked out and is not readable, but the book is most likely bound by Sangorski and Sutcliffe of London. Following Salar's travels through Devon's rivers, Salar the Salmon is a classic of naturalist literature and the New York Times review of the book called it "A rare and beautiful book that should take its place as a classic among the few that are written at once with a poet's insight and a naturalist's knowledge".

Spine with raised bands, each decorated with gilt dotted lines, and gilt ruled lines, decorations and lettering in the compartments. Board edges with gilt ruled lines. Turn-ins with double gilt ruled borders. Attractive marbled endapers. Neat colour bookplate on the front pastedown endpaper. All edges gilt. A finely bound copy of this popular work, containing many of the best poems and prose works about love written over many centuries, with most major writers in the English langauge represented.

Compartments double ruled and fully decorated in gilt. Dark green title label, gilt. Decorative panels and ruled line borders on boards, with floral corner decorations, all in gilt. Board edges with gilt ruled lines. Gilt inner Dentelles. Very dark green coated endpapers. All edges gilt. A few pages at the front of the text affected by light foxing but overall a very good clean copy in publishers cloth with colour illustrations and gilt lettering to the front board and spine. School prize label, dated 1920 on blank front free endpaper. A little bumping of the top and bottom of the spine but overall a superior copy of this scarce and interesting book. ----- The British Library gives a date of 1913, but the Author's preface is dated July 1912 and the technical details listed are all dated early 1912 or before suggesting the book may have been issued late that year, which coincides with the date that the Bodleian library attributes to their copy.

author: LAMI. EUGENE.
title: SOUVENIRS DE LONDRES.
description: FIRST EDITION. Oblong 4to. (13.8 x 9.8 inches). Illustrated with 12 fine hand coloured lithographs, engraved by de Villain. A scarce, complete copy with the 12 plates and the original publishers printed brown paper front wrapper and plain rear one mounted onto tabs and bound in. A very good example in a recent leather binding of half tan calf. Marbled paper on boards and a burgundy leather title label, ruled and lettered in gilt, on the front panel. Plain off-white endpapers. Some light spotting to the leaves but mainly in the plain margins. Overall a very good copy of this scarce and attractive work. --------- Starting with the Artist's rough crossing of the Channel and stage coach from Dover, The London scenes include Pall-Mall, Westminster Abbey, A Horse race, Boxing match, and Boat race. ----- The sketches for this work were drawn during Lami's first visit to England in 1826. '.... a set of a dozen delicately hand coloured lithographs. These were intended as a memento for for tourists from the Continent of their trip to London, illustrating the journey, the sights, and typical Anglo-Saxon diversions.' -- Bernard Adams: London illustrated. 1604 - 1851. No. 237. --- Gordon N. Ray: The At of the French Illustrated Book. 1700 to 1914. No. 138.

author: CARROLL. LEWIS. ; Tenniel. John. Illustrates.
title: ALICE'S ADVENTURES IN WONDERLAND. --- And --- THROUGH THE LOOKING GLASS, AND WHAT ALICE FOUND THERE.
description: TWO VOLUMES. 8vo. (7.6 x 5.3 inches). FIRST EDITION of Through the Looking Glass, Early edition of Alice's adventures in Wonderland (Sixteenth Thousand). This is the first issue of Looking-Glass, with the misprint "wade" for "wabe" in the second line of "Jabberwocky" on page 21. ------ Both volumes Illustrated throughout with forty-two (Alice) and fifty (looking Glass) line engravings by John Tenniel. Original tissue guard over the frontis in Looking glass still present. Some of the usual marking and thumbing to some of the pages in both volumes, but not seriously, and early previous owner name, dated 1869, in Alice and a neat three line inscription, dated Christmas 1871, in Looking Glass. Overall very good copies in recent full red morocco leather bindings. Single gilt ruled borders on boards. Spines with raised bands, the compartments ruled, lettered and decorated with gilt stamps of The Mad Hatter and playing cards. All edges gilt. Black endpapers. The original publishers red cloth front and rear boards , both sets marked and darkened to areas but included for completeness, have been bound in at the rear of each volume. Cloth with gilt circular devices on boards, each with a different character from the books inside, and triple gilt ruled borders. A very good attractive pair of books, both with two previous female owners names and inscriptions dated in the relevant years of publication, to the half titles. Both volumes housed in a felt-lined, cloth covered slip case with a pull tie. An attractive set.

author: KIPLING. RUDYARD.
title: IF.
publisher: Doubleday, Page and Company. New York. 1910
description: FIRST SEPARATE EDITION (U. S). IN PUBLISHERS DELUX GREEN LEATHER BINDING. Precedes the first U.K separate edition by 4 years.     Oblong 8vo. (4.4 x 6.4 inches). 8 double leaves, uncut at the top. Each double leaf has a red rule and dot border, the text printed in black with red initial letters. Half title has "IF" printed in red within an ornamental black panel, the same stamped in gilt onto the front board, with the addition of the author's name. Pages are sewn in with the original yellow cord.     The Publishers note on page 5 appears in four different variants, with priority unknown, and this copy has variant iii. In the rare original delux publishers dark green morocco leather binding with gilt ruling and lettering to the front panel (Richards binding variant i).     Neat previous owner name, dated 1914, on the front blank free endpaper. Inner hinges cracked at the endpapers but the book is firm in the binding. A little rubbing and fading to the edges of the binding but overall this is a very good, attractive copy of this fragile book.                               An attractive copy of this uncommon little book. Published (probably November 1910) very shortly after the Poem first appeared in the book Rewards and Fairies (October 1910), this separate publication was issued to capitalise on the huge, and instant, popularity of what has become Kipling's most enduring work of verse. A poll taken by the BBC in the UK in 2005 voted it as Britain's favourite Poem, poling twice as many votes as the number 2 choice, Lord Tennyson's The Lady of Shallot. Originally written in 1895, IF was inspired by the actions of Dr. Leander Starr Jameson, a British Officer whose forces were defeated by the Boers in 1895, but who was portrayed as a victorious hero by the British press, the poem is a powerful masterclass in maintaining the British stiff upper lip. --- Richards, A244.

Illustrated with seven maps, two leaves of illustratons of some of Sodor's Engines and five mono photos of the Rev. Awdry. Publishers blue cloth with gilt stamped image of Thomas the tank Engine to the front board and gilt lettering and ruled lines to the spine. A fine copy in a near fine original dustwrapper, illustrated in colour and gold, which has some minor creasing to the edges and a small production fault where the laminate on the front panel has creased in two places (see photo). ------ A detailed study of the fictional island of Sodor, the home to Thomas the Tank Engine and his friends, created by Wilbert and George Awdry, this is a rare volume which the publishers have not reprinted, with the added bonus of having The Rev Awdry's signature present.

author: RUSSELL. BERTRAND.
title: HISTORY OF WESTERN PHILOSOPHY. And its connection with political and social circumstances from the earliest times to the present day.
publisher: George Allen and Unwin Ltd. London. 1946
description: FIRST U. K  EDITION. 1st impression. 8vo. (8.8 x 5.9 inches). 916pp. A little light spotting to a few pages and the blank rear endpapers, otherwise a generally very good clean copy bound in the original publishers oatmeal cloth with brown and yellow stamped lettering panels to the spine. In the original dustwrapper, which was printed on re-used war-time paper with a colour map printed on verso. The wrapper has a couple of small chips on the spine edges and there are some minor areas of loss and marking to the rear panel but overall it is very good. ------- A presentable copy of Russell's hugely popular history, broadly covering covering philosophers and philosophical thought from the Pre-Socratics up to John Dewey and William James, and finishing with Logical Analysis. Russell won the Nobel prize for Literature in 1950, with the Nobel committee listing this title among the works that influenced their decision. While criticised by some as being too general, many found the book an accessible and easily readable introduction to Philosophy and it became a best seller which has not been out of print since.

author: COLERIDGE. SAMUEL TAYLOR. ; GRANT. GORDON, Illustrates.
title: THE RIME OF THE ANCIENT MARINER.
publisher: For members of the Heritage Club. New York. 1938
description: FIRST GRANT ILLUSTRATED EDITION. 4to. (11 x 8.7 inches). Beautifully illustrated throughout with 8 full page colour plates and each text page with tan ink printed line illustrations around the type. A fine, bright copy finely bound, for Asprey, in half black morocco. Spine with two raised bands, each with gilt piping. Compartments ruled and lettered in gilt. navy blue cloth on boards. Marbled endpapers. All edges gilt. The binding is signed by Aspreys in gilt letters to the bottom of the inside front board. There is no binders signature but this is certainly the work of a master bookbinder, very likely Sangorski and Sutcliffe, who did a lot of work for the firm. A truly handsome copy of this classic work. There was no UK edition published.    Volume designed by Carl Purington Rollins. The text is set in Bell type and printed on a rag paper made by The Worthy Paper Company.    Gordon Grant (18751962) was a noted American illustrator, best known for his maritime paintings.

author: JEROME. JEROME K.
title: THREE MEN IN A BOAT. To say nothing of the dog. -- Annotated and introduced by Christopher Matthew and Benny Green.
publisher: Nottingham Court Press. Pavilion Books Limited. London. 1983
description: DELUX LIMITED EDITION. 4to. (10.9 x 8.2 inches). Out of Series copy - Supposedly one of just 25 numbered copies, from a total edition of 100 copies, in full leather binding. Signed by Matthew and Green on the limitation page, but this copy is unnumbered and also does not include the map that was issued with the book. This delux edition used copies from the second impression. A fine, clean copy, finely bound in full blue morocco leather. Spine with two raised bands. Compartments with gilt lettering and ruled lines. Gilt stamped illustration, of the three men and dog in their boat, on the front board. All edges gilt. Gilt inner dentelles. Marbled endpapers. Housed in a blue cloth slip case. A fine copy of this informative and attractive edition. 'Jerome K. Jerome's masterpiece of English humour was first published in 1889. Although best remembered for its hilarious incidents and anecdotes, Jerome's story is also packed with detail and information concerning places visited, fads and fashions of the day, popular songs, shows and books. These contemporary allusions are annotated and explained by two modern-day humourists, Benny Green and Christopher Matthew. They have provided a virtual social history of the late nineteenth century which, combined with the many contemporary photographs and engravings, enhances even further the undisputed pleasure of reading the original book'.

author: REYNOLDS. JOSHUA.-- CARDINAL BINDING.
title: A COLLECTION OF 148 AQUATINTS OF REYNOLDS WORKS. Mounted onto blank leaves in a remboitage binding.
description: (8.7 x 6.1 inches). 148 small early nineteenth century aquatint plates of Reynolds works mounted onto blank leaves. The plates measurements range between about 1.5 inches tall up to about 4 inches for the largest. The blank leaves have been bound into an early Cardinal binding of full red morocco with elaborate gilt tooling. All edges gilt. A different spine, with decorative gilt tooling and the label titled 'Sir Joshua Reynolds' has been laid down, professionally and is certainly early. The whole book feels tight and the remboitage has been expertly done. Overall an attractive curiosity.

author: SALISBURY. E. J. --- FINE LEATHER BINDING.
title: THE LIVING GARDEN. Or The How & Why of Garden Life.
description: FIRST EDITION. 8vo. (8.8 x 6.1 inches). Illustrated throughout with 17 mono photos and 60 line drawings, some full page, mostly by Gwendy Caroe. A fine copy in an attractive mid twentieth century leather binding of full dark brown morocco with wrap around gilt design. Spine with five raised bands. Compartments with blind ruled lines. Both boards and spine with elaborate wrap around gilt floral design. Spine lettered in gilt. Board edges with gilt ruled lines. Inner boards with double gilt ruled line borders. Marbled endpapers. All edges gilt. A little fading to the spine but overall a fine and beautiful book. The binding is unsigned but is a beautiful fine quality binding by a master Bookbinder.

title: STORIES FROM THE ARABIAN NIGHTS. Retold by Laurence Housman.

Aside from the frontis before the title page the colour plates are all bound together at the back of the book, after the text. Some foxing to the first few pages otherwise a very good copy in the Publishers brown cloth binding with gilt lettering and decoration to the front board and spine. There is a neat repair to a split in the cloth at the top of the spine, about one inch deep. Overall a very good copy of this attractive book. -- Hughey; 16a.

title: THE TEMPLE. Sacred poems, and private ejaculations. Bound with: The Synagogue, or the shadow of the Temple by Christopher Harvey.

Spine with raised bands, each with gilt tooling. Compartments ruled, decorated and lettered in gilt. Decorative gilt panels to the boards. Board edges with gilt  dots. Turn-ins with decorative gilt roll. Marbled endpapers. Neat colour bookplate on the front pastedown endpaper. A very good copy of this famous work.

title: BILL THE MINDER. Written and illustrated by W. Heath Robinson.

A little fading to spine but overall a very good copy of this beautiful book. --- Geoffrey Beare. - The Illustrations of W H R. #69a.

title: ALICE IN WONDERLAND and THROUGH THE LOOKING-GLASS.
publisher: Collins' Clear-type Press. London. No date. 1928

Neat previous owner Bearsdley-esque bookplate to the front pastedown endpaper. Overall a very good clean copy in the publishers green cloth binding with gilt illustrations and lettering to the front board and spine. Some fading to the spine but still a very good copy of this delightful book. ---- The book is undated but the Lewis Carroll handbook gives the publication as October 1928. -- Williams, Madan, Green: The Lewis Carroll handbook no. 507d.

Spine with five raised bands, the compartments ruled, lettered and decorated in gilt. A single gilt wavy line border on both boards. Top edge gilt, the others untrimmed. Publishers adverts at end. author: RUFI. Q. CURTII. (Rufus. Quintus Curtius).
title: DE REBUS GESTIS ALEXANDRI MAGNI. (Alexander the Great). Libri Decem.
description: FIRST BARBOU EDITION. 12mo. (6.3 x 3.8 inches). xv, 557pp, + 3pp Catalogus praecipuarum Q. Curtii Rufi editionum at the end of the text. Engraved frontis, 2 vignettes and head and tail pieces by C. Eisen, engraved by Lempereur, and publishers illustrated device on the title page. Endpapers and first few leaves with some staining to the bottom of the page, more prominent on the dark blue endpapers, but barely noticeable on the white text pages, otherwise a very good bright copy throughout. In an atractive early full red morocco binding. Spine double ruled and beautifully decorated in gilt. Black morocco title label, gilt. Triple gilt ruled borders on both boards. Board edges with gilt ruled lines. Decorative gilt roll to the turn-ins. Dark blue endpapers. Green silk page marker. Armorial bookplate to the front pastedown and another, later bookplate on the blank verso of the front free endpaper. The rear board shows a faint stain to the bottom of the panel but overall this is a near fine, attractive copy of this classic work, first published in Venice in 1470, and running though many editions over the centuries. ---- Quintus Curtius Rufus remains an enigmatic figure. His Histories of Alexander the Great is uniquely isolated in Roman literature, as no other ancient text is known to reference either the work or the author.

author: EVANS. EDMUND.
title: THE ILLUMINATED SCRIPTURE TEXT BOOK. With Interleaved Diary for Memoranda and A Coloured Illustration for Every Day.
publisher: Frederick Warne and Co. London. No Date. Circa 1873
description: SECOND EDITION. Small 8vo. (4.3 x 2.9 inches). Colour frontis, colour printed text and decoration on title page and each text page with four colour and gold printed illustrations, one for each day. Blank leaves with ruled lines are bound in opposite each page, with a handfull filled in in ink with names and birth years on the relevant days. Neat three line inscription, gifting the book to a brother from his sister Annie, dated 1874, on the front free endpaper. Publishers highly decorative brown cloth binding with black decorations to the rear board. The front board and spine are decorated and lettered in black and gilt. Bevelled edges. Yellow coated endpapers. All edges gilt. Aside from the few names written into the diary dates, and a little gentle rubbing to the edges of the boards this is a fine copy of this beautifully produced book.

author: BARRIE. J. M. ; BEDFORD. F. D. Illustrates.
title: PETER AND WENDY.
publisher: Hodder and Stoughton. London. No Date. 1911
description: FIRST EDITION. 1st printing. Large 8vo. (8 x 5.8 inches). Complete with mono illustrated title and twelve full page plates by Bedford. Gilt decorated green cloth boards illustrated with Peter Pan, two Mermaids and the Crocodile, all within a decorative border, on front board. Spine with lettering and illustration including Captain Hook, Peter Pan, two Mermaids and some Fairies, all stamped in gilt. The gilt is very bright on the spine, but a little dulled to the front board. The cloth binding is clean and the corners still sharp. Although this copy has some foxing to about a quarter of the pages, it is mostly to the edges of the pages and generally the printed surface of the text and illustration pages are clean and bright. The endpapers have some offsetting as a result of the glue used in production. There is a previous owner's school prize presentation inscription, dated Christmas 1911, on the front free endpaper. A very good copy of this classic book. An attractive copy of the true First printing of this classic title, featuring Captain Hook, Never-Never Land, The Lost Boys, Nana and, of course, Tinkerbell (or Tinker Bell as she is named in this story).

author: GRONOW. CAPTAIN. -- Extra illustrated.
title: THE REMINISCENCES AND RECOLLECTIONS OF CAPTAIN GRONOW: Being Anecdotes of the Camp, Court, Clubs, and Society 1810-1960. -- With portrait and 32 Illustrations from contemporary sources by Joseph Grego, coloured by Hand.
description: ENLARGED GREGO EDITION. TWO VOLUMES. Large 8vo. (9 X 6 inches). Enlarged, with more illustrations, from the 1889 edition. Fully illustrated throughout with 32 hand coloured engraved plates by Joseph Grego, as called for, plus extra illustrated with another 86 eighteenth and nineteenth century plates bound in, a mixture of portraits and scenes from society, with many being hand coloured. A Lovely clean copy in fine twentieth century leather bindings. Half brown mottled morocco on the boards, with lighter brown colour on the plain spines. Both spines with five wide raised bands, each with four gilt ruled lines. Compartments with double ruled gilt borders. Two tan and one green label, ruled and lettered in gilt, to each spine. Boards covered with green cloth. Top edges gilt, the others untrimmed. Plain off white endpapers. Publishers original spines and front boards bound in at the rear of each volume. Neat previous owner colour bookplate on the front pastedown of volume one. A fine copy in a beautiful quality binding.

author: ROSSETTI. CHRISTINA.
title: POEMS. Chosen and edited by William M. Rossetti. ---- The Golden Treasury series.
description: Reprint of 1904 edition. Small 8vo. (6.1 x 4.2 inches). xxvi, 332pp. Portrait frontis, from a drawing made by Dante Gabriel Rossetti in 1865, still with its original plain tissue guard. Finely bound in very attractive early full dark brown morocco, extra gilt. The spine with raised bands each with a gilt floral decoration. Compartments decorated with gilt ruling, lettering, and elaborate floral design. Highly decorative floral design to boards in gilt, all within double gilt ruled and two dotted line borders. Boards wit gilt dotted lines to the edges. Inner Dentelles ruled fully decorated in gilt, surrounding off-white Moire silk centre pieces. Silk endpapers. All edges gilt. Neat three line inscription to the front blank endpaper. A little spotting to the blank endpapers at front and rear but the text pages are clean throughout. The binding is just a little rubbed to the extremities and some of the gilt on the boards a little dulled but overall this is a highly decorative, fine quality leather binding in very good condition. The binding is unsigned but is certainly the work of a highly skilled bookbinder.

author: CHURCHILL. WINSTON. S.
title: A SPEECH BY THE PRIME MINISTER... IN THE HOUSE OF COMMONS, AUGUST 20th 1940.
description: FIRST EDITION. Printed stapled wraps. 16pp. (9.5 x 6 inches). Staples a bit rusted but still firm. A few very minor small spots otherwise a bright, clean copy throughout. Overall a better than very good copy of this fragile pamphlet, much better than usually found.  Housed in a felt lined clamshell box with black morocco spine. Raised bands, the compartments ruled in blind, decorated with gilt stamped Rampant Lion device, and lettered in gilt. Black cloth on boards.  Printing and the mind of man. No.424 -----The Lion`s Voice. "If the Gettysburg Address is one of the most moving statements of democracy confronted by tragedy, Churchill`s historic exhortations are its equal in their ringing assertion of democracy confronting the seemingly irresistible forces of tyranny".  First edition of Churchill`s famous rousing speech, commenting on the first months of the war and giving thanks to British Airmen. "Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few".
